Technology of software development, A.V. Gavrilov

The course provides basic information on software development technology. Models and disciplines of Microsoft Solution Framework (MSF) are examined in detail. The main emphasis is on the use of theoretical knowledge in the implementation of a specific software project. The use of the team development environment is demonstrated using Visual Studio Team System (VSTS) as an example. The acquired skills allow for the design, analysis, and implementation of application software based on modern industrial development methods.

texts:
Recently, at a presentation organized by HTC for T-Mobile representatives, there was a leak of information about HTC's plans for next year.

So, the entire HTC product line will be divided into several categories:

Design / Lifestyle - smartphones aimed at the youth market segment: HTC Legend, HTC Salsa.
Social - youth smartphones aimed at tight integration with social networks (Twitter, Facebook, Flickr): HTC Tide, HTC Buzz.
Performance - smartphones with powerful performance: HTC Bravo.
Productivity - Windows Mobile smartphones designed for the business segment: HTC Photon, HTC Trophy, HTC Tera (a remake of Touch Pro2).

According to Eldar Murtazin, this roadmap does not include a couple of key HTC devices, such as HTC Espresso or the 10-inch Tablet HTC Halo running on Android.

Let's move on to the description of the most anticipated smartphone on Habrahabr.

HTC Bravo - the first Android smartphone from the company, based on the gigahertz Qualcomm Snapdragon QSD8250 processor, capable of recording HD video in 720p format, with 512 MB ROM and 256 MB RAM (rumors suggest that the RAM size will be increased to 512 MB). It also comes with a 16 GB MicroSD memory card and a 1400 mAh battery. It uses a 3.7" AMOLED capacitive touchscreen display. The launch date is in April 2010! An excellent competitor to the XPeria X10.

HTC Legend - another Android device that boasts a metal frame and a thickness of only 11.4 mm. Its specifications are more modest than the Bravo: a 600 MHz Qualcomm MSM7227 processor, a 3.2" capacitive display, 512 MB ROM, and 256 MB RAM. Judging by the shape, we can expect another sibling of the HTC Hero in March!

HTC Salsa - a gift for fans of both Blackberry and Android. Salsa is a beautiful monoblock device with a QWERTY keyboard and a small (by modern standards) resistive 2.6" display. The heart of the smartphone is the Qualcomm MSM7225 528 MHz processor. It also has the standard 512 MB RAM and 256 MB ROM. The release date is in June 2010.

HTC Tide - this is not a branded laundry detergent for HTC, but a new Android smartphone designed for fans of social networks like Twitter, Facebook, Plurk, Flickr, etc. In terms of specifications, the phone is similar to the HTC Salsa: Qualcomm MSM7225 528 MHz, 512 MB RAM, and 256 MB ROM. It has a 2.68" QVGA resistive touchscreen display. The release date is in April 2010.

HTC Buzz - a new incarnation of the HTC Tattoo, but this time much more attractive, very thin (11 mm), and with a capacitive 3.2" touchscreen display. Other specifications include Qualcomm MSM7225 528 MHz, 512 MB RAM, and 256 MB ROM. Those who like to emphasize their individuality with accessories will get a new toy in May 2010.

HTC Photon - a logical continuation of the HTC Diamond series, HTC Touch Diamond 2, but this time significantly improved, with a design similar to the HTC HD2. The device will also be equipped with a 3.2" capacitive HVGA display, a Qualcomm MSM7227 600 MHz processor, 512 MB RAM, and 256 MB ROM. The thickness of the smartphone is only 10.9 mm. The wait is almost over - April 2010!

HTC Trophy - another attempt to enter the Blackberry market, but this time the smartphone will run on Windows Mobile 6.5. It also features a pleasant design in the style of the HTC HD2, a 3" capacitive VGA display. The other specifications are standard: Qualcomm MSM7227 600 MHz, 512 MB RAM, and 256 MB ROM. It is worth noting that all HTC phones have significantly slimmed down: the thickness of the HTC Trophy is 11 mm. The premiere is in May 2010.

HTC Tera - nothing more than a remake of the HTC Touch Pro 2, but this time smaller, thinner, and more stylish. Qualcomm MSM7227 600 MHz, 512 MB RAM, 256 MB ROM, a 3.2" WQVGA resistive display, and a full QWERTY keyboard, but the most important feature is its thickness of 15 mm! The release date is in April 2010.

It is worth adding that the HTC HD2 will be the flagship product in the HTC product line throughout 2010, so buying it now means not regretting it in 3 months :) HTC is slowly getting rid of Windows Mobile phones, leaving them for the business market segment, while Android occupies the main niches. Geeks have already started saving up for the HTC Bravo, and I am too :)

HTC has done a tremendous job and seems to have outperformed everyone: Samsung with AMOLED displays, Blackberry with QWERTY monoblocks, and Apple with gigahertz processors and OpenGL ES 2.0 support.

texts:
In 1993, HP ProLiant servers appeared on the market for the first time, based on the x86 architecture. The ProLiant family expanded with new product lines as the scope of their use grew. Until recently, you could choose from the ML line - tower servers, which you usually buy individually; DL - rack machines for serious tasks, several of which you buy with a large margin for the future; and BL - by filling the rack with dozens of these blades, you can always add more if the demands increase.

But in recent years, BL and their counterparts have been used even when demands increase by tens and hundreds of times - in web search engines, large databases, and scientific supercomputers. And although various technologies are used in the construction of these servers to reduce power consumption and compactly place internal components, even a small power saving and a reduction in size at the level of a single server would provide significant economic benefits when operating complexes of several thousand computing nodes.

Therefore, HP specifically developed the HP ProLiant SL6000 line, in which a new form factor is used instead of the standard rack case. Our new system uses a two-unit z6000 chassis, in which several servers serve common power sources and fans. Compared to regular one-unit servers, power consumption is reduced by 28%, and the overall weight of the server rack is reduced by 31%. A similar solution is used in the BladeSystem chassis for the BL line, but the z6000 does not have a common backplane, which improves air cooling inside the chassis.

Like other HP ProLiant sixth-generation systems, depending on the equipment configuration, the z6000 can use three models of power supply: 460, 750, and 1200 watts. To simplify the deployment of large configurations, five SL6000 units can be installed in a single 10-unit bulk rail kit.

The z6000 can accommodate three types of one-unit dual-processor ProLiant SL server modules based on the Xeon 5500:

HP ProLiant SL170z is designed for data storage applications. For example, for search engines and databases. It can hold 6 full-size SAS/SATA disks and 16 DDR3 SIM memory modules.
HP ProLiant SL2x170z is designed for supercomputer calculations and serving front-end web applications. It occupies half the width of a 19-inch rack, so four SL2x170z modules are installed in the two-unit z6000 chassis, providing double the density of processor power compared to regular one-unit servers. This model also supports the installation of 16 DDR3 SIM memory modules, but only one 3.5-inch hard drive can be installed in it.
HP ProLiant SL160z, designed for applications that require intensive use of RAM (such as web page caching), is equipped with 18 slots for memory modules and two PCI slots. It can accommodate two 3.5-inch disks.

And soon, HP ProLiant SL165z modules based on the AMD Opteron 2400 Series will also be available for sale.

All four models are equipped with a dual-port Gigabit Ethernet adapter and support DCMI and IPMI management with the ability to turn off individual server modules in the chassis.

We can only sincerely wish that your tasks grow to such an extent that expanding your server fleet will mean purchasing several more HP ProLiant SL6000 cabinets! :)

It seems that there is a clear interest in Gibson and cyberpunk on Habr: they write about the adaptation of "Neuromancer" or about a comrade from Obscura Digital who waves his hands in the air just like Keanu Reeves in "Johnny Mnemonic".

Otherwise, people on Habr might start to worry why designer Mac Funamizu depicted Gibson's "Virtual Light" as a transparent frame instead of glasses. And it's completely unnecessary! Glasses with image processing of the surrounding world have long been implemented and are now being improved by enthusiast-cyborg Steve Mann:

Steve has been promoting the ideology of the "wearable" computer for several decades, first at MIT, and then at his alma mater, the University of Toronto.

The main areas Steve has been working on:
- Development of EyeTap technology. These are the very glasses that intercept the image entering the eye and, after passing it through a computer, transmit it further into the eye. One of the models ready for mass production:

- Image processing technologies. For example, Steve has a patent for the technology of stitching multiple video frames into a single image:

- CyborGLOGGING, reverse observation. Steve, as a respectable cyborg, develops and implements cyborg ideology. Cyborglogging, or simply glogging, is the continuous posting of videos and photos taken with "wearable" cameras. Steve even created a service for gloggers, where he himself keeps his own glog. Reverse observation is when instead of the all-seeing eye of Big Brother, the recording is done by a wearable device of an ordinary citizen, usually "wearable":

Such observation is naturally initiated not by government agencies for hidden control over citizens, but vice versa - by activists of the movement, for public use in diaries, all recorded information is maximally open. This is how Mann sees ideal observation: since the information is not secret, there can be no undercover games or corruption; if someone's rights are violated, everyone will see it. And if the recording itself invades someone's private life - no problem, because everything is maximally open, the information can be deleted immediately.

Cyborg problems
Now the most interesting part: Steve Mann is an ardent ideologist and activist of his inventions and concepts. Therefore, for the past three decades, he has been carrying a pile of iron on himself. This collage has been circulated in almost all internet publications, as you can see, up until the mid-90s Steve had a hard time (literally):

Another very interesting fact from Steve's life: on February 18, 2002, Steve was detained by airport security at St. John's Airport, Canada. Until that moment, Steve had been flying around the world without any problems, security services arranged his equipment package (which included a certificate from a personal doctor stating that Steve was conducting an experiment and it was not recommended for him to walk without special equipment). The New York Times writes: during a personal search, the officers scattered the devices all over the floor (then they forgot to return part of the equipment worth almost $57,000 to the inventor), they tore off the electrodes from Steve, which caused bleeding. After the electronics were disabled, Steve lost his sense of orientation (he fell several times, once hitting his head on a hanging fire extinguisher), and he was brought to the landing in a wheelchair.

I found an interesting discussion about the incident on Slashdot. Several former and current students of Steve's responded. They claim that the journalists greatly exaggerated everything, the students personally saw how Steve sometimes takes off his glasses and moves normally, that the inventor's equipment does not contain any biometric sensors, let alone implants. One of the MIT students of Steve speculated that if you stare at a two-dimensional image of the world (through the screens of the glasses) for a long time, disorientation will inevitably occur. Someone suggested that Steve was simply very upset about what happened. In any case, everyone agreed that this was a very indicative case from the series "what will happen if you deprive a person of gadgets that help him live."

Several photos
Here are some illustrations that allow you to immerse yourself in the atmosphere of what Steve does. Here is a group photo of MIT cyborg students participating in Steve's early project of scanning the surroundings of the institute:

Concept fantasy "PleaseWait: I don't talk to strangers." "Insert your passport into the reader on my head and only then will I see and hear you. If you want to show me an advertisement, pay for my attention. Press "3" and insert your credit card":

Wearable camera in a backpack:

Wearable camera on the chest in a bra:

One of the applications of Eyetap technology, the "Adissolve" project (literally "dissolving advertising"), in the illustration, the system recognizes advertising in a magazine and replaces it with a photo loaded from an art gallery:

The inventor's daughter, Christina Mann, captured through Eyetap glasses a few minutes after birth:

New hobby
Now Steve is fascinated with hydroinstruments, but he still doesn't part with his glasses:

Links
I recommend continuing to explore the topic through the following links:

- Eyetap Lab website
- Steve Mann's website
- "info gargoyle" blog dedicated to cyborgs and wearable computers
- Publication "Continuous Lifelong Capture of Personal Experience with EyeTap"
- Publication "Equiveillance: The equilibrium between Sur-veillance and Sous-veillance"

texts:
Indestructible "nuclear briefcase".
Legend of the "wild nineties".
Practically the same "briefcase with a horn", more authentic than only trunking communication devices and "RusAltai" blocks.
Previously belonged to some cool guy's car, thanks to his careful handling, the device is in very good condition. It is difficult to find better props for movies about nuclear missiles, spies, and satellite communication with the president.

Below are several photos and a story about this phone.

Analog mobile phone, more precisely a "portable subscriber radio station of the NMT-450 standard". It was used in the network of the operator MCC ("Moscow Cellular Communication"), which was widely known in the advertising of the "Federal network SOTEL".
There are no SIM cards, the number is hard-programmed in the network. SMS is not supported. At all. Voice mail worked "great" through the operator's means. The "phone book" is a memory for several speed dial numbers without search and familiar navigation.

Excellent reception quality was provided by a 7W transmitter (compare it with the power of GSM devices, which rarely reaches one watt). Confident operation at the maximum distance from the base station and unparalleled autonomous operation time from onboard batteries - a 1700mAh NiMH battery with a weight of over 500 grams squeezed out up to 7 days. This device is designed to provide communication in any circumstances, and it always succeeded.

The charger is connected directly to the battery, but it can also be connected to the phone - it has a power input for connection to the onboard network of a car or another power source.

The adapter of the wired telephone line allowed this device to emulate PBX and make calls through it using a modem, fax, or regular wired telephone. A distant wooded area, a stump, an ordinary telephone set with a handset connected to the line jack on the hidden Nokia 720. Lift the handset. After a second, a familiar dial tone is heard. You can dial the number.

They say that there are no longer any active networks of this standard - the analog NMT-450 protocol quietly died even in the regions of Russia. There is no longer that range, that autonomy, that power. You can no longer find that mystery, riddle, prestige that this device gave to its owner. The quality was a legend. Genuine Made in Finland.

The past has irretrievably gone, but this device will live on. It has seen even more. It is one of those devices that marked the beginning of cellular communication as a phenomenon. One of the best devices. It is not its fault that the standard is no longer supported, and all successors have not inherited its best qualities. They will still remain valuable.

UPD.
Can anyone tell if there are any NMT-450 networks still operating in any region?
This question was asked on the netmonitor, apparently the guys went somewhere supposedly to catch it, but I never saw a report about that trip.

UPD2.
Equipped weight with battery - 1500 grams. The bottom of the device is a ribbed metal radiator.

Year of manufacture - 1996.

IE6 (Microsoft Internet Explorer 6) was released in 2001. If you look at the date of this post, it is now 2008. Various statistical data show that about 20% of internet users still use IE6 today. It is also worth noting that the share of IE6 has been rapidly decreasing since the beginning of 2008.

IE6 does not support standards, does not provide adequate security, and contains a huge number of errors. To ensure compatibility with IE6, separate and labor-intensive work is required to track the errors of IE6 itself. Moreover, since 2001, the Internet has not stood still and has rapidly developed towards the so-called Web 2.0, and the use of all the latest technologies is not possible in IE6. For example, the use of complex JavaScript scripts.

Many internet services have officially discontinued support for IE6, including Facebook and Apple's MobileMe.

Thus, today we have a problem: on the one hand, 20% of internet users use IE6, and on the other hand, not all websites can be made compatible with IE6 due to the outdated nature of the browser.

Why do users not update this outdated browser? If you read the forums, you can note one trend. IE6 is a corporate standard for some companies, and corporate software has been created specifically for it, which is only compatible with IE6. This is the reason why corporate computers are not updated to the new version of IE, and the installation of third-party browsers, such as Firefox, Opera, or Safari, is prohibited by security policy.

(If we are not only talking about corporate computers, it is worth noting that Windows Update is enabled by default in Windows XP, and the IE6 browser is automatically updated to IE 7 without any problems.)

Thus, we have found that IE6 is currently a unique browser that requires writing special code to make a website compatible with it.

I believe that for this reason, developing a website compatible with IE6 can be a separate item in the technical specification for website development. If there is a task to create a modern website compatible with IE6, it is a task to develop two websites. The first one is compatible with all the latest browsers, and the second one may have slightly reduced capabilities, but is compatible with the outdated IE6.

One possible solution to the problem of using IE6 may be to detect the browser version and display a warning message stating that "the site may not work and look as expected because you are using an outdated browser," and offer to update the favorite browser to the latest version. This is how the aforementioned internet services handled it in the article.

UPD: Microsoft has created a website with statistics on the use of IE6.

The social network of the company "KM Online" has found its next incarnation. The same network that has been doing well for a long time under the name Classmates.km.ru (copying the name of the parent site Classmates.com), and then briefly and ingloriously lived under the nickname Odnoklassniki.km.ru (losing a legal dispute over intellectual property to Odnoklassniki.ru), has now received a name that can be recognized as the longest domain name in the Russian Internet - KakZdorovoChtoVseMyZdesSegodnyaSobralis.ru. "KM Online" wants to include this achievement in the "Guinness Book of Records".

The creativity of the creators of KZCHVMZSS.ru puts one at a loss with its scale and truly makes one think. Just think of these words from the press release: "The name of the network is a line from a song by Oleg Mitiaev. Initially, it was planned to quote the entire verse of the song in the address bar. But in order not to tire the user too much, the site creators stopped at the most popular words." Damn, people with such energy could really bypass the technical limitation on the length of a domain name of 63 ASCII characters!

It should be noted that there are already about 3.2 million users in the network who have experienced (or are experiencing) its heyday of active promotion in the Russian Internet. Which is quite a lot, considering that they themselves are unlikely to confidently remember the name of their haven now.

And finally. "Unlike competitors, the social network KakZdorovoChtoVseMyZdesSegodnyaSobralis.ru will only provide free services. Convenient search for friends by interests, place of study, work, individual informers, convenient blog service, 'invisible' status, and much more. Most of these services are absent in competitive social networks." The competitors mentioned directly in the same text are "Vkontakte" and "Odnoklassniki.ru". All that's left is to throw up your hands.

texts:
In LiveJournal, there is a blog called bablaw, whose author also goes by the pseudonym Hacker in Law. This blogger is one of the most cited on Habrhabr LiveJournal; yes, I myself referred to him yesterday.

And yesterday, this blogger posted an open letter addressed to President Medvedev. It should be noted that, like any such letter written from lawyer to lawyer, it is abundant in legal terminology; perhaps, for the readers of Habrhabr, a summary of the essence of the matter, prepared by Nesterovich, will be more understandable.

What do we see in essence? - we are faced with an attempt by Rostekhnadzor (formerly Gosstandart) to transfer state technical regulations from the public domain to the realm of intellectual property of individual organizations (perhaps even foreign ones). Not only are the funds of taxpayers, which were used by the creators of the GOSTs and which were transferred to the public domain, being wasted; moreover, now ordinary people are facing a new danger, for example, living in houses and flying in airplanes that are built according to outdated "pirated" copies of standards and regulations, or even with disregard for them.

Such an attempt is not new; however, last time (as Nesterovich points out) the state standardizers lost the case when they were sued by representatives of the non-profit organization from St. Petersburg (Institute for the Development of Freedom of Information). Nevertheless, the court decision on the free publication of GOSTs on the Internet has not been implemented, and the director of the IDFI even came under attack by unknown individuals in his own entrance, resulting in a head injury. Now a new attempt at privatizing standards is being made under the auspices of President Medvedev himself.

The fourth part of the Civil Code was criticized a lot and deservedly so, but it still contained Article 1259, according to which official documents of state bodies, official documents of international organizations, as well as their official translations, are not subject to copyright (and therefore cannot be the subject of licensing agreements with foreign rights holders, as the new bill makes them). Now, not only will a certain part of the legislation become available to citizens only for money as a result of all this; apparently, the way will be open for increasing this part. And the transfer of the text of laws into the greedy hands of copyright traders (especially international ones) should be as prohibited as the privatization of the Ministry of Finance or the anti-drug service, for example.

Events are unfolding very quickly: the bill on the privatization of GOSTs has already passed the first reading in the State Duma, and yesterday evening (in emergency mode, after the end of the working day) it was recommended by the Committee of the State Duma on Economic Policy and Entrepreneurship for submission to the Council of the State Duma. Today, the Council of the Duma will decide to recommend this bill for adoption, and tomorrow (December 23) it will be voted on in the second and third readings by a majority of votes. This once again proves how actively, obediently, and promptly the Duma serves as the legislative stamp of the President's will.

Therefore, the open letter calls on Medvedev himself to reconsider his decision and reprimand the copyright traders. Concerned citizens have already mentioned the open letter in Medvedev's blog; I believe it would be interesting to bring this story to the front page of Habrhabr.

This is a vocal fight for one's rights, this is truly a civil society.

texts:
On the W3C website, there is a draft called "The Capture API" - it describes a JavaScript interface that allows a website to access the visitor's computer's video camera and microphone, and to take photos, record videos, and audio. This draft summarizes the ideas of similar proprietary APIs (such as Google and Nokia).

And it makes me think dark thoughts knowing that the "Security and Privacy Considerations" section in this document only talks about the site not being able to take photos, record videos, and audio without the visitor's consent (i.e., the owner of the client computer or mobile phone).

But what about the privacy of other people? Remember the July scandal with the English head of external intelligence, who was exposed by his own wife on Facebook, literally down to his underwear, even though he never registered on Facebook himself? Now, when websites are preparing to see through the eyes of others through photo and video cameras, the whole world can be open to their gaze.

Imagine a website where visitors can continuously transmit live video frames from their own mobile phone cameras to this site (geo-tagged by GPS, tilted by the accelerometer, rotated by the digital compass), and at the same time observe any point on the Earth through the eyes of other digital observers. Something like Google Street View, but in real time. Simply by turning the mobile phone in different directions while standing in one place on Earth (for example, in Ufa), you can choose to look "through" its screen (like through a window) at the panorama of any other point on Earth - like New York, San Francisco, or Rio de Janeiro - as long as there are enough passers-by with the same mobile phones looking at the world through the same website. And at the same time, the electronic "eye" of your mobile phone will also survey and save the panorama of the point where you are standing on the site.

Exciting, unprecedented impression, isn't it?

And now imagine yourself as an ordinary person in a dense digital crowd.* You are under continuous surveillance by dozens of electronic eyes provided by anonymous volunteers. Any face and identity recognition system connected to such a site will easily track or reconstruct the entire history of your movements in the city, just like the branched internet banner system tracks your movements across all its sites. Your jealous, obsessed admirer will find out what flowers you bought for your wife, and your health insurance company will know how often you coughed while walking in the cold.

But in the real world, there is no Adblock Plus. It's not as easy to block the digital crowd as it is to block banner ads.

Bruce Sterling has a story called "Maneki-neko"; it's about something similar. In the comments, they suggest that William Gibson had something similar in his work. But one thing is fiction, and another thing is a draft API. The API draft is being prepared to become a reality.

___________

* This blog post introduces the new neologism "digital crowd" in the narrow sense of "a crowd of such people in the real world, whose digital photo and video cameras are used in a distributed network vision system." It may be generalized in the future to mean "a crowd of such people in the real world, whose behavior and resources are used for the purposes and needs of a network site".

If you remove ads by inserting code into the style of LiveJournal itself, first of all, it will surely be eliminated by SUP soon, and secondly, it contradicts the notorious Terms of Use.

Fortunately, modern browsers allow users to block ads on their side.

Insert this code into a text document.

div.adv {display: none;}
div.ljad {display: none;}
div.ljadleaderboard-bottom {display: none;}
div.ljadleaderboard {display: none;}
div.ljadwrapper-journal-after-post-c {display: none;}
div.ljadwrapper-app-home {display: none;}
div.ljadmedrect {display: none;}

Save it as userContent.css.

For Mozilla Firefox:
Save the file in:
Linux: ~/.mozilla/firefox/RANDOM_CHARACTERS.PROFILE_NAME (default is "default")/chrome
XP: C:\Documents and Settings\USERNAME\Application Data\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles\PROFILE_NAME\chrome
Vista: C:\Users\USERNAME\AppData\Roaming\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles\PROFILE_NAME\chrome
Mac OS X: Library > Application Support > Firefox > Profiles > PROFILE_NAME > chrome
(if there is no Application Data or AppData folder: Start > Control Panel > select Switch to Classic View on the left > launch Folder Options > View tab > check Show hidden files and folders in the Hidden files and folders section). Restart the browser.

For Internet Explorer:
Save the file anywhere on the disk and specify the path to it in IE settings: Tools menu > Internet options menu > General tab > Accessibility button > check the Format documents using my style sheet checkbox > enter the path to the file in the Style sheet field.
In the Russian version: Service menu > Browser properties menu > General tab > Style button > check the Format using user style checkbox > enter the path to the file in the Style list field. Restart the browser.

For Opera:
Save the file anywhere on the disk and specify the path to it in Opera settings: Tools menu > Preferences menu > Advanced tab > select Content on the left > Style Options button > Display tab > enter the path to the file in the My style sheet field > Presentation Modes tab > check both My style sheet checkboxes.
In the Russian version: Tools menu > Settings menu > Advanced tab > select Content on the left > Style Options button > Display tab > enter the path to the file in the My style sheet field > Presentation Modes tab > check both My style sheet checkboxes. Restart the browser.

For Safari:
Save the file anywhere on the disk and specify the path to it in Safari settings: Edit menu > Preferences menu > Advanced tab > select Other... in the Style Sheet dropdown menu > select the file.
In the Russian version: Edit menu > Preferences menu > Advanced tab > select Other... in the Style Sheet dropdown menu > select the file. Restart the browser.

The code should remove all ads, including ads in the profile and on the home page.

texts:
In the second half of 2009, both in e-mail and in LiveJournal, I saw a spreading wave of murky spam advertising erotic social networks, which had the following common disgusting features:

1) Their names were pornographic versions of popular social networks - either "Classmates" ("One-lovers", "One-nighters", "One-fuckers", etc.) or "In contact" ("In XXX-contact", "In sex-contact", etc.), imitating their interface (like phishing) and being located on a domain that corresponded to the name.

2) The home page displayed miniature photos of naked women (supposedly users), sometimes with pop-up or labeled elements from profiles (as far as I could tell, names and profiles were randomly substituted, and the city was determined by the visitor's IP). The total number of registered users was exaggerated (if the possibility of searching or separate counting of registered users by cities was imitated, then in a small city you could "find" many tens of thousands of profiles, more than the number of internet users).

3) They offered to register for a modest fee by sending a paid SMS. However, in the rules, in small print (and in a color close to the background color of the site), it was explained that the price was indicated per day, and the payment was taken for a month or several months in advance, and even such SMS messages were offered to be sent under some pretext. Therefore, the real price turned out to be a hundred times higher than the deceptive one.

In general, everything was clear with them.

Now, however, there are sites appearing on the horizon that are not clear at all. They do not seem to mimic phishing, and they do not even ask for money for registration, but they ask for the number of the mobile phone to which they will supposedly send an access code to the site. As an example, take a look at "RusssErotika.com" (pay attention to the triple "s" in the domain; I will not provide hyperlinks).

So what is the new trick? There must be a trick because it is clear to everyone: it is much cheaper to send registration codes to users by e-mail rather than by SMS.

Are they disguising subscription confirmation for paid incoming SMS messages as an access code? Or are they collecting mobile phone numbers for resale to spammers? Or is it simply that after free registration, everything else is incredibly expensive, like in the "Economic" hotel from Nosov's immortal satirical fairy tale about Neznaika on the Moon?

Who knows?

And again, "the perfect IDE for PHP" from JetBrains ^) Since the previous release, we have managed to create an official website, visit ZendCon'09, and finally work on promised performance optimization. We also had time for a few new features. While the build is downloading, take a look below - in addition to the usual details, there will be a few words about ZendCon and the unique features of the platform/WI.

ZendCon'09
Before the conference, there were tutorials - for me, the PHP on IBM I5 session was a revelation. IBM has joined forces with Zend to bring PHP to mainframes. If we set aside the i5 ecosystem, this can also have significant implications for everyone else, especially if IBM helps develop the language core. Some optimizations have already been introduced in 5.3, but judging by other more "mature" technologies, there is still a lot of work ahead.

The keynote (and most sessions) were very lively and optimistic - this year PHP 5.3 was released, a new ZendStudio appeared (and specifically released version 7.1 for the conference), the entire Zend stack and toolkit continue to improve, in general, the language, platform, and community are moving forward :)

During lunches and while most people were in sessions, we had quite a lot of conversations with Zend employees - and even impressed some of the ZendStudio developers with our technologies. In turn, we were interested to hear about their work on the Eclipse platform and how they help coordinate efforts with the Eclipse Foundation. After all, JetBrains is a relatively small company :) From an engineering perspective, it was interesting to hear about work on the language core and automatic profiling (especially from the perspective of a seasoned Java web developer).

What's new in this release
Impressed by conversations with users at ZendCon, we focused on optimization. As "stress tests," we used heavyweights like ShugarCRM and Magento (we wanted to try Bitrix, but couldn't find a version with open source code). Literally, the first profiling sessions showed that type inference was producing too much "garbage" in memory and could lead to looping (and hanging) - these issues are now fixed. I want to emphasize that this is just the initial optimization, and we plan to seriously work on it further. We *really* want to hear feedback from everyone who has upgraded. If you have specific issues, please write in any way. I personally handle all feedback.

New features:
- Improved PHPDOC generation
- Navigation/search for global variables
- Recognition of class members based on name in cases where type inference is not possible
- SFTP support
- Autocompletion after the "new" keyword
- Namespace display in the file structure tree
- Quick fix (Alt-Enter) for defining unknown variables using "var"

Many bug fixes, details in the blog and tracker.

Unfortunately, there are also known issues:
- The most serious one is degradation: multiline literals in this build are incorrectly highlighted as containing an error WI-494
- Several namespace declarations XXX; (specifically with ";") in one file will be mistakenly recognized as nested WI-497
- Renaming a variable removes the $ sign from the name WI-500

We will try to release an update as soon as possible. Expect bug fixes, optimizations, and of course, new features :)

Something about hidden features of WI
The release is approaching, and we have started gathering all the information about WebIDE features in one place. Even if you are already familiar with the editor, I recommend at least reviewing the list. And here I will tell you about a couple of very useful but not quite obvious features. So, if your PHP project is used for generating XML, JS, CSS, SQL, or any other language supported by WebIDE, you can comfortably work with the following functions:

"External" language for PHP
For each file or folder, you can set an "external" language relative to PHP instead of the default HTML through the Settings|Template Data Languages panel. This setting is remembered in the project file.

"Internal" language for a string literal in PHP
Inside the literal, press Alt-Enter and select "Inject Language," then choose the required language. Currently, it is NOT remembered. In the future, you will be able to specify that, for example, the first string parameter of the query() function is SQL (and select the dialect).

Both cases will include full language support - including completion and refactoring. By using these features, you can get full support for any combination of languages %)

That's all, and I'm waiting for any questions and suggestions :)

Asus Bookshelf PC

Asus Bookshelf is a computer consisting of interchangeable modules that allows for easy upgrade/downgrade by simply replacing or adding the necessary module.

MADE in China by John Leung, winner of the Next-Gen PC Design Competition, represents traditional Eastern design.

Prime Gaming Laptop

Prime Gaming Laptop by Kyle Cherry solves the problem of limited laptop size and portability of a powerful gaming computer.

Portable PC Theater
